text: What service, again, does all the labour spent in arranging the hair render to salvation? Why is no rest allowed to your hair, which must now be bound, now loosed, now cultivated, now thinned out? Some are anxious to force their hair into curls, some to let it hang loose and flying; not with good simplicity: beside which, you affix I know not what enormities of subtle and textile perukes; now, after the manner of a helmet of undressed hide, as it were a sheath for the head and a covering for the crown; now, a mass (drawn) backward toward the neck. The wonder is, that there is no (open) contending against the Lord's prescripts! It has been pronounced that no one can add to his own stature.[fn-4-P433_91113:61-nf] You, however, do add to your weight some kind of rolls, or shield-bosses, to be piled upon your necks! If you feel no shame at the enormity, feel some at the pollution; for fear you may be fitting on a holy and Christian head the slough[fn-4-P434_91383:62-nf] of some one else's[fn-4-P435_91417:63-nf] head, unclean perchance, guilty perchance and destined to hell.[fn-4-P436_91557:64-nf] Nay, rather banish quite away from your "free"[fn-4-P437_91619:65-nf] head all this slavery of ornamentation. In vain do you labour to seem adorned: in vain do you call in the aid of all the most skilful manufacturers of false hair. God bids you "be veiled."[fn-4-P438_91839:66-nf] I believe (He does so) for fear the heads of some should be seen! And oh that in "that day"[fn-4-P439_92016:67-nf] of Christian exultation, I, most miserable (as I am), may elevate my head, even though below (the level of) your heels! I shall (then) see whether you will rise with (your) ceruse and rouge and saffron, and in all that parade of headgear:[fn-4-P440_92289:68-nf] whether it will be women thus tricked out whom the angels carry up to meet Christ in the air[fn-4-P441_92458:69-nf] If these (decorations) are now good, and of God, they will then also present themselves to the rising bodies, and will recognise their several places. But nothing can rise except flesh and spirit sole and pure.[fn-4-P442_92698:70-nf] Whatever, therefore, does not rise in (the form of)[fn-4-P443_92796:71-nf] spirit and flesh is condemned, because it is not of God. From things which are condemned abstain, even at the present day. At the present day let God see you such as He will see you then.
title: Book II.
author: Tertullian

text: But as to their scrupulosity concerning meats, and their superstition as respects the Sabbaths, and their boasting about circumcision, and their fancies about fasting and the new moons, which are utterly ridiculous and unworthy of notice,-I do not[fn-6-P661_118968:12-nf] think that you require to learn anything from me. For, to accept some of those things which have been formed by God for the use of men as properly formed, and to reject others as useless and redundant,-how can this be lawful? And to speak falsely of God, as if He forbade us to do what is good on the Sabbath-days,-how is not this impious? And to glory in the circumcision[fn-6-P662_119445:13-nf] of the flesh as a proof of election, and as if, on account of it, they were specially beloved by God,-how is it not a subject of ridicule? And as to their observing months and days,[fn-6-P663_119656:14-nf] as if waiting upon[fn-6-P664_119699:15-nf] the stars and the moon, and their distributing,[fn-6-P665_120387:16-nf] according to their own tendencies, the appointments of God, and the vicissitudes of the seasons, some for festivities,[fn-6-P666_120595:17-nf] and others for mourning,-who would deem this a part of divine worship, and not much rather a manifestation of folly? I suppose, then, you are sufficiently convinced that the Christians properly abstain from the vanity and error common [to both Jews and Gentiles], and from the busy-body spirit and vain boasting of the Jews; but you must not hope to learn the mystery of their peculiar mode of worshipping God from any mortal.
title: The Epistle of Mathetes to Diognetus
author: Mathetes

text: Let us now see whether the apostle withal observes the norm of this name in accordance with Genesis, attributing it to the sex; calling the virgin Mary a woman, just as Genesis (does) Eve. For, writing to the Galatians, "God," he says, "sent His own Son, made of a woman,"[fn-5-P598_134932:23-nf] who, of course, is admitted to have been a virgin, albeit Hebion[fn-5-P599_135014:24-nf] resist (that doctrine). I recognise, too, the angel Gabriel as having been sent to "a virgin."[fn-6-P600_135155:25-nf] But when he is blessing her, it is "among women," not among virgins, that he ranks her: "Blessed (be) thou among women." The angel withal knew that even a virgin is called a woman.
title: III. On the Veiling of Virgins.
author: Tertullian

text: This, he says, is ocean, "generation of gods and generation of men"[fn-10-P1017_267285:63-nf] ever whirled round by the eddies of water, at one time upwards, at another time downwards. But he says there ensues a generation of men when the ocean flows downwards; but when upwards to the wall and fortress and the cliff of Luecas, a generation of gods takes place. This, he asserts, is that which has been written: "I said, Ye are gods, and all children of the highest; "[fn-10-P1018_267693:64-nf] "If ye hasten to fly out of Egypt, and repair beyond the Red Sea into the wilderness," that is, from earthly intercourse to the Jerusalem above, which is the mother of the living;[fn-10-P1019_267920:65-nf] "If, moreover, again you return into Egypt," that is, into earthly intercourse,[fn-10-P1020_268018:66-nf] "ye shall die as men." For mortal, he says, is every generation below, but immortal that which is begotten above, for it is born of water only, and of spirit, being spiritual, not carnal. But what (is born) below is carnal, that is, he says, what is written. "That which is born of the flesh is flesh, and that which is born of the spirit is spirit."[fn-10-P1021_268445:67-nf] This, according to them, is the spiritual generation. This, he says, is the great Jordan[fn-10-P1022_268552:68-nf] which, flowing on (here) below, and preventing the children of Israel from departing out of Egypt-I mean from terrestrial intercourse, for Egypt is with them the body,-Jesus drove back, and made it flow upwards.
title: Book V.
author: Hippolytus

text: He is not undone,[fn-10-P1082_284872:109-nf] he says,[fn-10-P1083_284943:110-nf] but revolves as it were, and goes round himself. Moreover, also, cities in which we dwell, because we turn and go round in them, are denominated "Poleis." In this manner, he says, the Phrygians call this one "Aipolis," inasmuch as he everywhere ceaselessly turns all things, and changes them into their own peculiar (functions). And the Phrygians style him, he says, "very fruitful" likewise, "because," says he, "more numerous are the children of the desolate one, than those of her which hath an husband; "[fn-10-P1084_285505:111-nf] that is, things by being born again become immortal and abide for ever in great numbers, even though the things that are produced may be few; whereas things carnal, he says, are all corruptible, even though very many things (of this type) are produced. For this reason, he says, "Rachel wept[fn-10-P1085_285830:112-nf] for her children, and would not," says (the prophet), "be comforted; sorrowing for them, for she knew," says he, "that they are not."[fn-10-P1086_286089:113-nf] But Jeremiah likewise utters lamentation for Jerusalem below, not the city in Phoenicia, but the corruptible generation below. For Jeremiah likewise, he says, was aware of the Perfect Man, of him that is born again-of water and the Spirit not carnal. At least Jeremiah himself remarked: "He is a man, and who shall know him? "[fn-10-P1087_286452:114-nf] In this manner, (the Naassene) says, the knowledge of the Perfect Man is exceedingly profound, and difficult of comprehension. For, he says, the beginning of perfection is a knowledge of man, whereas knowledge of God is absolute perfection.
title: Book V.
author: Hippolytus
